title: Before and After
prompt: Draw an item before and after it has been used (for example: a new eraser and a used one, a peeled and unpeeled banana, or a clean and used plate).
goal: Notice small changes caused by use.
howTo: Split the page into two parts. Keep the item the same size in both drawings.

title: Only the Outline
prompt: Draw an everyday item using only its outer outline (for example: your shoe, water bottle, or pencil case).
goal: Focus on overall shape instead of details.
howTo: Move your pencil slowly around the edge. Do not draw inside details.

title: One Continuous Line
prompt: Draw a continuous line drawing of an everyday item (for example: your shoe, headphones, or water bottle).
howTo: Do not lift your pencil once you begin. Keep your eyes on the item and move slowly.

title: Upside Down
prompt: Draw an item upside down (for example: a shoe, stapler, or pair of scissors).
goal: Break habits of drawing from memory.
howTo: Turn the item or the paper upside down and draw exactly what you see.

title: Two Angles
prompt: Draw the same item from two different angles (for example: a chair from the front and side, or a bottle upright and tilted).
howTo: Split the page into two sections and rotate the item slightly.

title: Close-Up Detail
prompt: Draw one small part of an everyday item very large (for example: the cap of a bottle, the corner of a book, or the sole of a shoe).
howTo: Choose a small area and let it fill most of the page.

title: Cut Off
prompt: Draw an item so part of it goes off the edge of the page (for example: a chair, backpack, or shoe).
howTo: Let the drawing extend beyond the paper. Do not try to fit everything in.

title: Touch Points
prompt: Draw only where an item touches the table or floor (for example: chair legs, the bottom of a bottle, or the sole of a shoe).
howTo: Ignore the rest of the item. Draw only the contact areas.

title: Big and Small
prompt: Draw the same item once very big and once very small (for example: your shoe filling the page, then drawn tiny in a corner).
howTo: Use most of the page for one drawing and a small space for the other.

title: Blind Drawing
prompt: Draw an everyday item without looking at your paper (for example: your shoe or pencil case).
howTo: Keep your eyes on the item the whole time. Do not correct mistakes.

title: Edges Over Time
prompt: Draw worn edges of an item that is used often (for example: a book corner, desk edge, or shoe sole).
goal: Notice signs of use over time.
howTo: Focus on corners and edges rather than the whole form.

title: Before Cleaning
prompt: Draw an item before and after it has been cleaned (for example: a dirty plate and a clean one, or dusty shoes before and after wiping).
goal: Notice subtle changes in surface and detail.
howTo: Split the page into two equal sections.

title: Inside and Outside
prompt: Draw the inside and outside of the same item (for example: a backpack open and closed, or a pencil case zipped and unzipped).
howTo: Use a cutaway view or split the page in two.

title: Shadow Shapes
prompt: Draw only the shadow shapes made by an item (for example: a bottle or chair under a light).
howTo: Ignore the object itself and draw only the shadow.

title: From Below
prompt: Draw an item as seen from below (for example: a chair seat, desk underside, or hanging bag).
howTo: Change your position and draw what you actually see.

title: From Above
prompt: Draw an item as seen from directly above (for example: your desk, notebook, or lunch box).
howTo: Look straight down and draw carefully.

title: Only Corners
prompt: Draw only the corners or joints of an item (for example: chair joints or book corners).
howTo: Skip flat surfaces and details.

title: Slow Look
prompt: Spend one minute looking at an item, then draw it slowly (for example: a shoe or bottle).
howTo: Do not rush marks once you begin drawing.

title: Memory Then Look
prompt: Draw an item from memory first, then look at it and add what you missed (for example: your shoe or backpack).
howTo: Use about half the time for memory and half for looking.

title: Overlapping Items
prompt: Draw two everyday items overlapping (for example: a notebook on top of a book).
howTo: Decide which item is in front before you begin.

title: Negative Space
prompt: Draw the space around an item instead of the item itself (for example: the gaps around chair legs).
goal: See shapes made by empty space.
howTo: Outline the spaces between and around the item.

title: Partial View
prompt: Draw only half of an item (for example: half a shoe or half a bottle).
howTo: Let the viewer imagine the rest.

title: Repeated Item
prompt: Draw the same item three times (for example: your shoe) each time slightly faster.
howTo: Do not erase. Let each drawing be looser.

title: Loose Then Careful
prompt: Draw an item once loosely and once carefully (for example: a backpack or bottle).
howTo: Use the same item both times.

title: Final Observation
prompt: Draw an everyday item of your choice slowly and carefully (for example: your shoe, bag, or desk).
howTo: Focus on accuracy over speed.

title: Before and After Magic
prompt: Draw an everyday item before and after something magical happens to it (for example: a shoe that can fly, or a bottle that never empties).
howTo: Split the page into two parts. Change only one or two features.

title: Secret Inside
prompt: Draw an everyday item with something hidden inside it (for example: a backpack with a secret room, or a book hiding a world).
howTo: Use a cutaway or opening to show what is inside.

title: Strange Version
prompt: Draw a normal item in a strange version (for example: a chair with only one leg, or a pencil that bends).
goal: Use imagination while keeping the item recognizable.
howTo: Change only one thing about the item.

title: Living Object
prompt: Draw an everyday item as if it were alive (for example: a backpack that slouches or a lamp that looks curious).
howTo: Add posture, movement, or expression.

title: Pocket World
prompt: Draw a tiny world that could fit inside a small container (for example: a city in a matchbox or a forest in a jar).
goal: Explore scale in a playful way.
howTo: Include both very small and very large elements together.

title: Future Version
prompt: Draw a common item as it might look in the future (for example: a futuristic backpack or phone).
goal: Imagine change while keeping purpose clear.
howTo: Change only one or two features.

title: Creature With a Job
prompt: Draw a creature that has a simple job (for example: cleaning, carrying, or guarding).
howTo: Decide the job first, then design the creature.

title: Broken and Fixed
prompt: Draw an item broken and then fixed (for example: a cracked screen or a torn shoe that has been repaired).
howTo: Split the page into two parts and show the repair clearly.

title: Moving Furniture
prompt: Draw a piece of furniture that can move on its own (for example: a chair that walks or a desk on wheels).
howTo: Show how the furniture moves.

title: Friendly Machine
prompt: Draw a machine designed to help people (for example: a robot that organizes books).
howTo: Keep shapes simple and clear.

title: Strange Vehicle
prompt: Draw a vehicle designed for an unusual place (for example: a snow vehicle, underwater bus, or desert bike).
howTo: Think about where it travels.

title: Object With Memory
prompt: Draw an everyday item that shows its past through marks or changes (for example: a scratched desk or worn backpack).
howTo: Add marks that suggest history.

title: Temporary Item
prompt: Draw an item meant to disappear after use (for example: an ice sculpture or sand drawing).
howTo: Show how it begins and ends.

title: Object That Reacts
prompt: Draw an item that reacts to weather or surroundings (for example: shoes that grow in rain or a hat that shrinks in sun).
howTo: Decide what triggers the reaction.

title: Tiny Helper
prompt: Draw a tiny helper creature that assists with a daily task (for example: organizing pencils).
howTo: Show its size clearly next to objects.

title: New Use
prompt: Draw an everyday item being used in a new way (for example: a book as a bridge or a shoe as a planter).
howTo: Keep the original form recognizable.

title: Dream Version
prompt: Draw an everyday item as it appears in a dream (for example: floating shoes or melting clocks).
howTo: Change one or two features.

title: Object With Sound
prompt: Draw an item that makes a sound (for example: a bell, alarm clock, or speaker).
howTo: Use lines or shapes to suggest sound.

title: Object That Floats
prompt: Draw an item floating in the air or water (for example: a chair floating in a room or a bottle in water).
howTo: Show floating clearly.

title: Room Inside Room
prompt: Draw a small room hidden inside a larger room (for example: a secret room inside a classroom).
howTo: Show how the spaces connect.

title: Tool for One Task
prompt: Draw a tool made for one very specific task (for example: a machine that erases mistakes).
howTo: Make the task clear through the drawing.

title: Object That Grows
prompt: Draw an item that grows over time (for example: shoes that grow with you).
howTo: Draw at least two stages.

title: Object That Shrinks
prompt: Draw an item that shrinks over time (for example: a backpack that gets smaller).
howTo: Show before and after.

title: Object With Feelings
prompt: Draw an everyday item showing an emotion (for example: a sad chair or excited lamp).
howTo: Use posture or shape to show emotion.

title: Final Imagination
prompt: Draw an everyday item of your choice imaginatively (for example: your shoe or backpack with a creative twist).
howTo: Keep the drawing simple and clear.
